name: Executive Dashboard Build
description: Design and build an executive dashboard that provides leadership with real-time visibility into key business metrics. Includes requirements gathering, metric selection, data architecture planning, and dashboard design - stopping short of actual technical implementation.

painPoints: Executives don't always know what they want until they see it

currentProcess.description: Audit existing data sources and availability
painPoints: Data quality issues in source systems
Information hierarchy is hard to get right
Translating business needs to technical specs
Handling edge cases and missing data

currentProcess.description: Review and iterate on designs with stakeholders
painPoints: Aligning on priorities when you can't fit everything
Comprehensive enough for engineering to build
Clear enough for stakeholders to approve
Documenting what's in scope vs future phases

currentProcess.description: Plan for ongoing maintenance and updates

aiProcess.toolRationale: Claude can generate comprehensive, thoughtful interview guides
aiProcess.expectedOutput: Role-specific interview questions for CEO, CFO, VPs
tips: Include questions about decisions they need to make

aiProcess.toolRationale: Human interaction required; AI helps with prep and notes

aiProcess.description: Synthesize requirements and propose metric framework
aiProcess.toolRationale: Claude excels at organizing and prioritizing information
aiProcess.expectedOutput: Prioritized metric list with hierarchy and rationale

aiProcess.description: Research dashboard best practices and examples
aiProcess.toolRationale: Perplexity finds real examples and design patterns
aiProcess.expectedOutput: Reference examples, design principles, and anti-patterns
tips: Look for both good and bad examples

aiProcess.toolRationale: Claude can describe layouts in detail; you'll translate to wireframes
aiProcess.expectedOutput: 2-3 layout options with rationale for each
tips: Specify your tool constraints (Tableau, Looker, etc.)
Ask for text descriptions you can mock up

aiProcess.toolRationale: Claude can translate business requirements to technical specs
aiProcess.expectedOutput: Data specification document for engineering team
tips: List all metrics with calculation logic
Include data sources, refresh frequency, and edge cases

aiProcess.toolRationale: Human facilitation; AI helps with quick iterations

tips: Include what's in scope AND what's out of scope
Create a 'future enhancements' section for stakeholder requests you deferred

aiProcess.expectedOutput: Maintenance plan, ownership matrix, training outline

whyItMatters: Executive dashboards drive organizational visibility and accountability. A poorly designed dashboard leads to wrong decisions, wasted engineering effort, and loss of executive trust. Good dashboards (like BigQuery pipelines at AAA) can save thousands of hours.
commonMistakes: Too many metrics - executives want 5-10 KPIs, not 50 data points
Building before specifying - rushing to code without clear requirements
Ignoring data quality - garbage in, garbage out
No owner - dashboards without maintenance become stale and ignored
Wrong level of detail - executives want trends and exceptions, not raw data
tips: Start with 'what decisions will this dashboard inform?' not 'what data do we have?'
Use AI to generate metric definitions - ensures consistency and clarity
Ask AI to critique your dashboard design: 'What's confusing about this layout?'
Create a 'question bank' - what questions should this dashboard answer?
Plan for v2 from day 1 - keep a backlog of deferred features
sources: Stephen Few - Information Dashboard Design (best practices)
Aditya Goyal AAA Experience - Executive dashboard building, BigQuery pipelines saving 2,000+ hours
